skill.name: geniml
skill.description: Genomic interval machine learning toolkit for training embeddings on BED files, scATAC-seq data, and building consensus peak universes
skill.summary: Machine learning toolkit for genomic interval analysis with embedding models
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged 179 findings, but evaluation shows these are false positives. The 'external_commands' are documentation examples of legitimate genomics tools, 'weak cryptographic' findings refer to MD5 checksums (not encryption), and network/filesystem patterns are normal documentation URLs and cache directories.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation example showing legitimate geniml CLI usage: 'geniml bedspace preprocess --input /path/to/regions/' - this is proper tool documentation, not code execution
This is likely an MD5 checksum used for file integrity verification in genomics workflows, not encryption. MD5 is appropriate for checksums despite being cryptographically broken
Documentation URL pointing to legitimate genomics resources (likely StarSpace GitHub repository), not a security risk

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] filesystem: "Hidden file in home directory" at references/utilities.md:23
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: BBClient cache directory '~/.bedcache' is a standard pattern for application caches in home directories, not suspicious
R integration example using reticulate library - legitimate bioinformatics workflow pattern for cross-language interoperability
Likely references genome assembly files or chromosome size files which are standard genomics reference data, not system probing
Documentation reference to remote data sources or APIs in genomics workflows - legitimate scientific data access patterns

content.user_title: Analyze genomic intervals with machine learning
content.value_statement: Geniml transforms BED files into machine learning embeddings for genomic region analysis. Train models to find patterns in chromatin accessibility, build consensus peak sets, and analyze single-cell ATAC-seq data.
actual_capabilities: Train embeddings on genomic regions from BED files
Build consensus peak universes from multiple experiments
Analyze single-cell ATAC-seq data with specialized models
Create joint embeddings for regions and metadata labels
Evaluate embedding quality with multiple metrics
limitations: Requires pre-processed BED files as input
StarSpace dependency needed for BEDspace models

use_cases.title: Compare ChIP-seq experiments
use_cases.description: Train region embeddings to find similar peaks across different transcription factor binding experiments

use_cases.title: Cluster cells by chromatin
use_cases.description: Use scEmbed to analyze scATAC-seq data and identify cell types based on chromatin accessibility patterns

use_cases.title: Build reference peak sets
use_cases.description: Create consensus universes from multiple ATAC-seq experiments for standardized analyses

prompt_templates.title: Train region embeddings
prompt_templates.scenario: I have BED files from ChIP-seq experiments
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me train region2vec embeddings on my BED files. First tokenize them using a universe file, then train a 100-dimensional embedding model.

prompt_templates.title: Analyze scATAC-seq
prompt_templates.scenario: I need to cluster single cells
prompt_templates.prompt: Use scEmbed to analyze my scATAC-seq data in scanpy. Tokenize the cells, train an embedding model, and generate UMAP visualization.

prompt_templates.title: Build consensus peaks
prompt_templates.scenario: I have multiple peak sets to combine
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a consensus universe from my collection of BED files using the coverage cutoff method with 5x threshold.

prompt_templates.title: Joint region-label embeddings
prompt_templates.prompt: Train BEDspace embeddings on regions with cell type labels to enable cross-modal queries between regions and metadata.

output_examples.input: Train region2vec on my ATAC-seq peaks and evaluate the embeddings
output: âœ“ Tokenized 15,234 peaks using universe file
âœ“ Trained 100-dimensional embeddings for 8,567 unique regions

best_practices: Always build high-quality universes with good peak coverage before training embeddings
Validate tokenization coverage (>80%) and adjust p-value thresholds if needed
Use multiple evaluation metrics to assess embedding quality and biological relevance
anti_patterns: Training on low-quality or misaligned peak sets without proper universe building
Using default parameters without tuning for your specific data type and scale
Skipping evaluation steps - always validate embeddings before downstream analysis

faq.question: What file formats does geniml support?
faq.answer: Geniml works with standard BED files (3+ columns) for genomic regions and CSV files for metadata.

faq.question: How do I choose embedding dimension?
faq.answer: Start with 100 dimensions for most analyses. Use 50 for small datasets, 200+ for complex multi-label scenarios.

faq.question: Can I use geniml with other single-cell tools?
faq.answer: Yes, scEmbed outputs integrate seamlessly with scanpy as adata.obsm embeddings for clustering and visualization.

faq.question: What's the difference between Region2Vec and BEDspace?
faq.answer: Region2Vec trains on regions only. BEDspace jointly embeds regions and metadata labels for cross-modal queries.

faq.question: How long does training take?
faq.answer: Minutes for small datasets (1000s of regions), hours for large collections. Use GPU for scEmbed on big single-cell data.

faq.question: Do I need a universe file?
faq.answer: Yes, for tokenization. Build one with consensus peaks or use a reference like ENCODE SCREEN.
